head.title: Irish At Center Of Volatile Situation

hedline.hl1: Irish At Center Of Volatile Situation

block.p: The luck of the Irish may have extended to Charlottesville and Lincoln, where losses Saturday by Virginia and Nebraska enabled Notre Dame to reclaim the top spot in the news-agency polls. But giving up 31 points to lowly Navy dropped the Irish in The Times's computer ranking from No. 9 to No. 11.

Notre Dame was placed first by both The Associated Press and United Press International, while The Times's computer put Washington, which qualified for the Rose Bowl on Saturday by routing Arizona, 54-10, on top. The Huskies occupied the second spot in both the news-agency lists. First Losses
The losses by Virginia (to Georgia Tech, 41-38, on a last-seconds field goal) and Nebraska (to Colorado, 27-12) were their first of the season and resulted in large slides in the rankings.

The luck of the Irish may have extended to Charlottesville and Lincoln, where losses Saturday by Virginia and Nebraska enabled Notre Dame to reclaim the top spot in the news-agency polls. But giving up 31 points to lowly Navy dropped the Irish in The Times's computer ranking from No. 9 to No. 11.

Notre Dame was placed first by both The Associated Press and United Press International, while The Times's computer put Washington, which qualified for the Rose Bowl on Saturday by routing Arizona, 54-10, on top. The Huskies occupied the second spot in both the news-agency lists. First Losses
The losses by Virginia (to Georgia Tech, 41-38, on a last-seconds field goal) and Nebraska (to Colorado, 27-12) were their first of the season and resulted in large slides in the rankings.

The Cavaliers, who had been on top of both news-agency polls and The New York Times computer ranking one week ago, dropped to fifth in the computer listing, to ninth in United Press International's poll of coaches and to 11th in The Associated Press's poll of writers and broadcasters. Nebraska's first loss caused it to skid in the computer rating from fourth to eighth, in the United Press International listing from second to 10th and in The Associated Press poll from third to 13th.

Georgia Tech, whose record is blemished only by a 13-13 tie at North Carolina on Oct. 20, used its dramatic triumph over Virginia to move from third to second place in The Times's ranking, from ninth to sixth in the United Press International poll and from 16th to 7th in the voting by the writers and broadcasters.

Colorado (8-1-1), which rallied in the final period to beat Nebraska, took over the lead in the Big Eight Conference and moved up from seventh to third place in both The Times's and the United Press International listings. In The Associated Press's poll, the Buffaloes moved up from ninth to fourth. Jump for Iowa

With its convincing 54-28 shellacking of Illinois at Champaign, Iowa took over the favorite spot in the Big Ten race and hopped from 15th to seventh in The Times's ranking and up from 13th to fifth, according to the coaches' evaluations.

Auburn, after suffering a brutalJU 48-7 beating at Florida for its first loss of the season, fell in the computer listing from fifth to 17th, and the Gators soared from 10th to fourth. Auburn dropped from fourth to 13th in the United Press International listing and from fourth to 15th in The Associated Press's.

In the computer listing, Houston maintained its sixth position with a 56-35 victory over Texas Christian. It moved to third in The Associated Press's poll (the Cougars, who are on National Collegiate Athletic Association probation, are not considered by the coaches.

Brigham Young moved from 14th to ninth on the computer after drubbing Air Force, 54-7. It is ranked sixth and eighth by United Press International and The Associated Press, respectively. Clemson jumped from 12th to 10th in the computer ranking after beating North Carolina, 20-3. The Tigers are ranked 16th and 18th by United Press International and The Associated Press.

Miami, despite having two losses, rose to fourth on the United Press International list after blanking Pittsburgh, 45-0. The Hurricanes are No. 5 in The Associated Press's poll and No. 12 in The Times's ranking.
